TopicTitle: Go To Mun, EVA with kerbal. Then press Spacebar when outside ship.

Articles.Content: I didn't know you could do this, is it new?

What happened?

I can't get on KSP right now

I can tell you with 100% certainty that it has always been possible for you to physically press your spacebar while having a kerbal out on EVA.

The question remains, however, what exactly happens when you press spacebar? If we don't know that, we can't answer your question.

I thought pressing spacebar simply means letting go, so you can hop around on the surface.. or press R for jetpack and fly around.

Also, wrong section.

I didn't know you could do this, is it new?

Um, do what? Doesn't that just make the kerbal let go of the ladder? And when on the ground, jump?
Yes jump, I never knew he could jump, I take its not new then?
Definitely not. Have you found the jetpack yet? May I suggest a look at the key bindings section of the wiki. Will help a lot by the sounds of it.
No not new. You should try it on a low grav body like Minmus. Feels like he's going to return to orbit.
Nope been around forever.

No not new. You should try it on a low grav body like Minmus. Feels like he's going to return to orbit.

In fact I believe the EVA report has a comment about a Kerbal's jumping ability while on Minimus. I won't say it here, but I'm sure you could look it up or better yet, perform your own Minimus mission.

No not new. You should try it on a low grav body like Minmus. Feels like he's going to return to orbit.

Try it on Gilly then if you're really feeling brave
Gilly has such low gravity that whenever I do develop a lander for it it will probably just be powered by RCS.
How about reeling in KAS grapple hooks? This is how I 'landed' a probe on a no-gravity asteroid.

Try it on Gilly then if you're really feeling brave

I did. I think he got to about 200m above the surface before starting to drop back again.

Gilly has such low gravity that whenever I do develop a lander for it it will probably just be powered by RCS.

Wish I'd though of this. I used the same lander I did for Duna and it to took me about half an hour to nail a landing, then a further 20 minutes to get the thing to sit stable on the ground. In the last 1000 metres or so I got so bored of waiting whilst moving at about 4m/s that I decided to EVA and go get the surface sample and plant a flag while I waited. When I got back it had hardly moved more than a couple hundred metres

Try it on Gilly then if you're really feeling brave

ROFL...i did jump on Gilly once without fully appreciating what would happen....

Made me a bit nervous at first... thank Bog for jet packs !

Wish I'd though of this. I used the same lander I did for Duna and it to took me about half an hour to nail a landing, then a further 20 minutes to get the thing to sit stable on the ground. In the last 1000 metres or so I got so bored of waiting whilst moving at about 4m/s that I decided to EVA and go get the surface sample and plant a flag while I waited. When I got back it had hardly moved more than a couple hundred metres

You increase downward speed to land on Gilly get an downward speed of 20m/s and its no issue. Just do an normal braking and float down the last meters.

More fun you can do eva reports from space close to the surface on Mun by jumping.

You increase downward speed to land on Gilly get an downward speed of 20m/s and its no issue. Just do an normal braking and float down the last meters.

More fun you can do eva reports from space close to the surface on Mun by jumping.

That you can do already when standing on the rocket^^
While on the ladder press shift space, then R then press and hold shift.
And you can press and hold Space to turn off the annoying mouse-relative camera during EVA too!

JUMP AROUND! JUMP AROUND! JUMP UP, JUMP UP AND GET DOWN!

OK, I'll go to the Mun in sandbox mode, see what this is really all about...

Of course actually getting something to land ON gilly is the big challenge there. i finally gave up using my regular lander designs and threw together and open cockpit with a seat, and rcs thrusters.

alacrity
